system.description:
General

Cure light wounds allows the cleric to lay hands upon a wounded creature, restoring [[/roll 1d8]] hit points to the spell's beneficiary.

This spell does not heal disease, reattach limbs, or bring back the dead, nor can it add hit points beyond a character's normal number.

The reverse of this spell is Cause Light Wounds.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

Non-corporeal creatures are not affected by this spell, nor are undead.

actions.name: Cure Light Wounds
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Target the actor to be healed
  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (steps to this point may already have been done)
  • Click on the "Heal 1d8" action to apply it to the target actor

system.description:
[Foundry Note: two aura versions of this spell are provided (one where the benefits are provided to players and allies, and another casting for enemy actors which reverses the buff/debuff fields). The player aura version is recommended as the mechanical changes are automatically transmitted to all combatants in the caster-centered AOE via the aura. The caster need only self-apply both buff/debuff spell actions.

A legacy non-aura version is also provided if auras aren't preferred.  As "friendlies" and "enemies" is always from the POV of the players (only), enemy casters should apply the buff when targeting "hostiles" and debuff when targeting "friendlies". - Ed.]

 

General

Once the spell is cast, the cleric must maintain a sonorous chanting of holy words and prayers, which not only lend divine favour to the cleric and his or her allies but also bring disfavour to their foes.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The cleric must remain stationary and continue to chant.

If the cleric sustains damage, is grappled, or is in some way silenced, the effect of the spell will end.

 

Combat Effects

While the spell is in effect his or her allies (within the area of effect) gain a bonus of +1 to all attack rolls, damage rolls, and saving throws.

Enemies within the spell's area of effect also suffer a -1 to all such die rolls.

actions.name: Chant
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done).
  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Target friendly actors in the AOE and click the  "Allied Chant Buffs - Indefinite (F)" action
  • Target enemy actors in the AOE and click the  "Enemy Chant Buffs - Indefinite (E)" action

actions.name: Chant (Aura Version - Player Cast)
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the caster and click the  "Allied Chant Buffs - Indefinite (F)" action
  • Target the caster and click the  "Enemy Chant Debuffs - Indefinite (E)" action

actions.name: Chant (Aura Version - Enemy of Players Cast)
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the caster and click the  "Allied Chant Buffs - Indefinite (F)" action
  • Target the caster and click the  "Enemy Chant Debuffs - Indefinite (E)" action

actions.name: Chant (Aura Version - Enemy of Players Cast)
Chant (Aura Version - Enemy of Players Cast)

system.description:
General

This spell is used to slow the progress of poison through the body. Even a person who has died from poison may be revived if he succumbed to the poison within a number of turns less than or equal to the caster's level of experience.

The spell does not eliminate or neutralise poison; it merely slows it.

The spell is generally used to keep someone alive until the poison can be neutralised completely by other means, such as a Neutralise Poison spell.

 

Combat Effects

A poisoned creature will lose 1 hit point per turn (but will not fall below 1) during the spell's duration; once the spell's protection expires, the victim will suffer the full potency of the poison.

actions.name: Slow Poison
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the poisoned actor and click the  "Slow Poison - Duration (T)" action

actionGroups.name: Slow Poison

system.description:
[Foundry Note: when the spell isn't centered on an individual (by choice or successful saving throw), a spell NPC is provided at bottom which can be dropped on the map to establish via aura a fixed 15' radius AOE. A second duration effect is also provided for use when the spell doesn't center on an individual, which can be applied to the caster instead. Delete the spell NPC from the map when this duration runs out.

This may help the GM identify silenced individuals in the area of effect (perhaps only until they move away). - Ed.]

 

General

The spell may be cast upon a location in the air, upon a physical object (in which case it will move with the object), or upon a creature (in which case a saving throw is applicable).

 

Saves and Other Impediments

If the creature makes a saving throw, the area of silence will centre upon the space just behind the intended victim.

 

Combat Effects

Casting this spell brings into being an area of complete and utter magical silence in which no sound can be heard.

[And which obviously prevents the casting of any spell in the area of effect which has verbal components. - Ed.]

 

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.actor.Actor.iYX4rLckDBcGPTxE]{Silence 15' Radius, Fixed AOE}

actions.name: Silence 15 ft Radius
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • (if the spell is cast to be centered on a target) target the actor
  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (these may already have been done)
  • Click the "Save vrs Spell" action (this may not be necessary if the cast with an embedded save was used)
  • If the save fails, click the  "Silenced - Duration (T)" action to activate the (visual-only) aura
  • No further steps apply for a successful centered combat casting
  • If cast specifically as a fixed AOE (or if a target makes their saving throw), add the @UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.actor.Actor.iYX4rLckDBcGPTxE]{Silence 15' Radius, Fixed AOE} spell NPC to the scene to show the GM a freestanding silence zone
  • Add the Silence 15' Radius token to the combat tracker - this is necessary for the automatic token death to work
  • Target the spell NPC and click the "Freestanding Silence - Duration Autokill" effect

actions.name: Silence 15 ft Radius

  • Target the spell NPC and click the "Freestanding Silence - Duration Autokill" effect

system.description:
[Foundry Note: although Prayer's description neglects to mention the caster's enemies, they're also affected (with penalties) as discussed in the referenced Chant spell.

two aura versions of this spell are provided (one where the benefits are provided to players and allies, and another casting for enemy actors which reverses the buff/debuff fields). The player aura version is recommended as the mechanical changes are automatically transmitted to all combatants in the caster-centered AOE via the aura. The caster need only self-apply both buff/debuff spell actions.

A legacy non-aura version is also provided if auras aren't preferred.  As "friendlies" and "enemies" is always from the POV of the players (only), enemy casters should apply the buff when targeting "hostiles" and debuff when targeting "friendlies". - Ed.]

 

General

Casting prayer is a matter of intoning an invocation to the cleric's god(s), following which any of the cleric's allies who were in the spell's area of effect will gain, for the duration of the spell, the same benefits as if they were affected by an ongoing Chant spell.

Note that the cleric is able to move and take other actions while the Prayer spell is in effect, which is not the case with the more restricted Chant spell.

 

Combat/Damage

REFERENCED TEXT: 

...his or her allies (within the area of effect) gain a bonus of +1 to all attack rolls, damage rolls, and saving throws.

Enemies within the spell's area of effect also suffer a -1 to all such die rolls.

actions.name: Prayer
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done).
  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Target friendly actors in the AOE and click the  "Allied Prayer Buffs - Indefinite (F)" action
  • Target enemy actors in the AOE and click the  "Enemy Prayer Buffs - Indefinite (E)" action

actions.name: Prayer (Aura Version - Player Cast)
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the caster and click the  "Allied Prayer Buffs - Indefinite (F)" action
  • Target the caster and click the  "Enemy Prayer Debuffs - Indefinite (E)" action

actions.misc:

  • Target the caster and click the  "Enemy Prayer Debuffs - Indefinite (E)" action

Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the caster and click the  "Allied Prayer Buffs - Indefinite (F)" action
  • Target the caster and click the  "Enemy Prayer Debuffs - Indefinite (E)" action

system.description:
General

Upon completion of the ritual words of this spell, food and/or water will appear from thin air. A caster of fifth level can conjure up enough food and water to sustain a person or even a horse for five full days.

The volume of food and water produced by the spell is approximately one cubic ft per level of the caster.
system.areaOfEffect: A day's ration per caster level

actionGroups.name: Create Food and Water
actionGroups.description:
General

Upon completion of the ritual words of this spell, food and/or water will appear from thin air. A caster of fifth level can conjure up enough food and water to sustain a person or even a horse for five full days.

The volume of food and water produced by the spell is approximately one cubic ft per level of the caster.

biography.value:
Ousseawin, Silver Tide of Sehanine

Born to a human father and an Elven mother in a quiet borderland village, Ousseawin grew up straddling two worlds, never fully belonging to either. Her silvery hair and piercing green eyes marked her as different, even among her kin. Her life, shaped by duality, mirrored the cycles of the moon that came to symbolize her patron deity, Sehanine Moonbow.

From a young age, Ousseawin displayed an affinity for the divine, often wandering under moonlight and speaking to the stars as if in prayer. Her mother, an enigmatic herbalist with a deep connection to nature, named her after the Elvish phrase for "silver tide," a poetic homage to the moonlit streams of their woodland home. Her human father, a stoic wanderer, instilled in her a sense of resilience and the value of hard work.

Shadows and Light

Ousseawin’s idyllic life shattered when brigands killed her father while he was defending their family. Fleeing with her mother into the wilderness, they sought refuge among the Elves. But even in her mother’s homeland, Ousseawin’s mixed heritage marked her as an outsider. Her feelings of alienation deepened when tragedy struck again—her village was razed by raiders, leaving her a displaced child with nowhere to turn.

It was during this time that a wandering cleric of Sehanine Moonbow found her amid the ruins. Recognizing the divine spark within her, the cleric took Ousseawin under his wing, teaching her the tenets of faith and the healing arts. Through these teachings, Ousseawin grew into a devoted servant of Sehanine, embracing her role as a guide through the cycles of life and death.

Tending the Wounded of Badwall

Years later, when the town of Badwall was invaded by an army of orcs and monsters, Ousseawin found herself tending to a band of wounded refugees in the ruins of an abandoned chapel. She worked tirelessly, binding wounds, soothing frightened children, and offering prayers for the dead under the crescent moonlight.

It was here that Valerys Mystralath, the Elven mage, found her.

“You don’t stop, do you?” Valerys remarked, leaning against the broken arch of the chapel. Her emerald eyes glimmered in the dim light.

Ousseawin glanced up from the bandages she was wrapping around an older man’s arm. “When they stop bleeding, perhaps,” she replied evenly, her tone both weary and resolute.

Valerys stepped closer, taking in the scene. “You could leave them to their fate. It’s what the world expects.”

Ousseawin’s piercing green gaze met Valerys’s. “And what do you expect?”

A small smile tugged at Valerys’s lips. “More. From someone like you.”

The two spoke long into the night, discussing life, death, faith, and purpose. Impressed by Ousseawin’s determination and unique perspective as a half-elf, Valerys offered her a place in her retinue.

“You would leave this behind?” Ousseawin asked, gesturing to the refugees.

“I would see it never happens again,” Valerys replied. “But I need people like you to make that possible.”

Ousseawin considered the offer for only a moment before nodding. “If my goddess wills it, then I am yours to command.”

The Silver Tide and the Red Cloak

As Valerys’s henchwoman, Ousseawin quickly proved her worth. She embraced her role as a healer and spiritual guide, blending reverence for Sehanine with pragmatic action. Her heavy flail became an extension of her faith, delivering swift justice to the wicked. Her striking red cloak, a personal symbol of twilight and transition, marked her as both a warrior and a cleric.

Though she respects Valerys, Ousseawin is not afraid to challenge her decisions when her faith compels her to speak. She views their shared journey as part of Sehanine’s divine plan, believing that they were brought together to illuminate the darkness.

A Guiding Light

Ousseawin’s presence is both calming and commanding. She prays beneath the open sky, her silver pendant catching the moonlight as she murmurs hymns in Elvish. In battle, she calls upon Sehanine’s power to shield her allies and confound her enemies. In quieter moments, she reflects on the cycles of life and death, knowing that her faith is her greatest strength.

Her connection to Sehanine Moonbow defines her, but it is her unwavering resolve and compassion that make her a beacon of hope in the chaos of their adventures. The Silver Tide is a force to be reckoned with, whether offering solace to the wounded or wielding her flail against the forces of evil.

system.description:
General

It is possible for elves and humans to interbreed, although elven fastidiousness makes this a fairly uncommon occurrence. Half elves do not have a separate culture or civilisation of their own, usually assimilating into the elven or human society in which they were raised.

 

Summary of Half-Elven Racial Abilities

  • 30% resistance to sleep and charm spells

 

Detect secret doors: When searching, a half-elf character can detect:

  • secret doors on a 2 in 6
  • concealed doors on a 3 in 6 

When passing within 10 ft of a concealed door, a half-elf will notice it on a 1 in 6.

 

Languages:

  • common
  • elven
  • gnoll
  • gnome
  • goblin
  • halfling
  • hobgoblin
  • orcish

 

Multi-class restrictions: The less restrictive of any class requirements apply to multi-classed half-elven characters, except that thieving abilities can only be used while wearing armour permitted to thieves.

 

Permitted Class Options:

  • Assassin
  • Cleric
  • Druid
  • Fighter
  • Magic user
  • Ranger
  • Thief
  • Cleric/Fighter
  • Cleric/Ranger
  • Cleric/Magic user
  • Fighter/Magic user
  • Fighter/Thief
  • Magic user/Thief
  • Cleric/Fighter/ Magic user
  • Fighter/Magic user/Thief

 

Infravision: 60 ft

 

Movement Rate: 120 ft

 

Starting Age:

Cleric [[/roll 40+2d4]]
Fighter [[/roll 22+3d4]]
Magic User [[/roll 30+2d8]]
Thief [[/roll 22+3d8]]

[Foundry Note: sub-classes are as main class. if multi-classed, roll whichever of the classes included could produce the highest starting age. - Ed.]

 

Racial Limitations:

Minimum/Maximum ability scores (after adjustment for race); if the ability scores rolled do not fall within these limits, then the race of hal-elf is not a valid choice for the character:

Attribute Min Max
Strength 3 18
Dexterity 6 18
Constitution 6 18
Intelligence 4 18
Wisdom 3 18
Charisma 3 18

 

Level Limitations:

Assassin 11
Cleric 5
Druid 14
Fighter 8 (Str 18), 7 (Str 17 and below), 6 (Str 16 and below)
Illusionist N/A
Magic User 8 (Int 18+), 7 (Int 17), 6 (Int 16 and below)
Paladin N/A
Ranger 8 (Str 18), 7 (Str 17 and below), 6 (Str 16 and below)
Thief Unlimited

[Foundry Note:  This "weapon" is included in the non-lethal skill bundle and doesn't require a separate drop on an actor sheet. 

All characters can put this "weapon" in their inventory just as they would a dagger, etc.   All characters are proficient in all forms of unarmed combat without spending weapon proficiences; attach the like-named proficiency that comes with all classes to the weapon without having to spend any points.]

Unarmed combat: Brawling attacks, such as those conducted with fist, foot, or dagger pommel, will normally inflict [[/roll 1d2]] points of damage.

[ Note: All characters can put this "weapon" in their inventory just as they would a dagger, etc.   All characters are proficient in all forms of unarmed combat without spending weapon proficiences; attach the like-named proficiency that comes with all classes to the weapon without having to spend any points.]

Unarmed combat - grapple: A successful grappling attack inflicts 0-1 ([[/roll 1d2-1]]) points of damage, but also restrains the target and prevents him or her from fighting. The chance of breaking a successful grapple should be determined according to the relative strengths of the creatures concerned. (An ogre could restrain a kobold almost indefinitely, and would be able to break free of the kobold's grasp at will.)

actionGroups.name: Grapple: Restrained
actionGroups.description:
[ Note: All characters can put this "weapon" in their inventory just as they would a dagger, etc.   All characters are proficient in all forms of unarmed combat without spending weapon proficiences; attach the like-named proficiency that comes with all classes to the weapon without having to spend any points.]

Unarmed combat - grapple: A successful grappling attack inflicts 0-1 ([[/roll 1d2-1]]) points of damage, but also restrains the target and prevents him or her from fighting. The chance of breaking a successful grapple should be determined according to the relative strengths of the creatures concerned. (An ogre could restrain a kobold almost indefinitely, and would be able to break free of the kobold's grasp at will.)

system.description:
[ Note: All characters can put this "weapon" in their inventory just as they would a dagger, etc.   All characters are proficient in all forms of unarmed combat without spending weapon proficiences; attach the like-named proficiency that comes with all classes to the weapon without having to spend any points.]

Unarmed combat - overbearing: Overbearing attacks are Grappling attacks exercised at the end of a Charge (see "Charge" above). If successful, the opponent is prone rather than restrained. Otherwise the attack is treated as a grapple.

Referenced Text: A successful grappling attack inflicts 0-1 ([[/roll 1d2-1]]) points of damage, but also restrains the target and prevents him or her from fighting. The chance of breaking a successful grapple should be determined according to the relative strengths of the creatures concerned. (An ogre could restrain a kobold almost indefinitely, and would be able to break free of the kobold's grasp at will.)

Referenced Text: Charge: Charging into combat allows the attacker to move and then attack in the same round. A charge is made at twice the normal movement rate (and must terminate within the 10-ft melee range of the target). If the defender has a longer weapon than the attacker, the defender attacks first (unless the defender has already acted in this round). The attacker gains no dexterity bonus against such an attack (and characters with no dexterity bonus receive a +1 AC penalty). Additionally, if the defender has a weapon set against the charge (see below), he or she will inflict additional damage with a successful hit against the charging attacker.

Assuming that the charging character survives, he or she gains +2 "to hit" on his or her attack. Characters may only perform a charge once every 10 rounds (i.e. once per turn). Characters who are at the maximum encumbrance category may not charge unless they are mounted and the mount is below the maximum encumbrance category.

actionGroups.description:

Unarmed combat - overbearing: Overbearing attacks are Grappling attacks exercised at the end of a Charge (see "Charge" above). If successful, the opponent is prone rather than restrained. Otherwise the attack is treated as a grapple.

Referenced Text: A successful grappling attack inflicts 0-1 ([[/roll 1d2-1]]) points of damage, but also restrains the target and prevents him or her from fighting. The chance of breaking a successful grapple should be determined according to the relative strengths of the creatures concerned. (An ogre could restrain a kobold almost indefinitely, and would be able to break free of the kobold's grasp at will.)

Referenced Text: Charge: Charging into combat allows the attacker to move and then attack in the same round. A charge is made at twice the normal movement rate (and must terminate within the 10-ft melee range of the target). If the defender has a longer weapon than the attacker, the defender attacks first (unless the defender has already acted in this round). The attacker gains no dexterity bonus against such an attack (and characters with no dexterity bonus receive a +1 AC penalty). Additionally, if the defender has a weapon set against the charge (see below), he or she will inflict additional damage with a successful hit against the charging attacker.

Assuming that the charging character survives, he or she gains +2 "to hit" on his or her attack. Characters may only perform a charge once every 10 rounds (i.e. once per turn). Characters who are at the maximum encumbrance category may not charge unless they are mounted and the mount is below the maximum encumbrance category.

system.description: 30% resistance to sleep and charm spells

Thieves and assassins have an enhanced chance to hear noise as they gain levels (see “thief skills” in Chapter I). Characters of all other classes have a base 10% chance. This should be modified by race; elves, gnomes, halflings, and half-orcs have a base 15% chance.  (In Foundry, these races have a 5% bonus added to their skill check target number automatically when the skill is used- Ed.)

 

Hear - Base Chance/Target Formula

Assassin Thief
Level  Target Range Level Target Range
1 10% 1 10%
2 10% 2 13%
3 10% 3 16%
4 13% 4 19%
5 16% 5 22%
6 19% 6 25%
7 22% 7 28%
8 25% 8 31%
9 28% 9 34%
10 31% 10 37%
11 34% 11 40%
12 37% 12 43%
13 40% 13 46%
14 43% 14 49%
15 46% 15 52%
    16 55%
    17 58%
    18 61%
    19 64%
    20 67%
    21 70%
    22 73%
    23 76%
    24 79%

 

Normally the GM rolls this die in secret, because the player has no way of knowing whether no noise was heard because of the roll or because there was no noise to hear. A character who fails (or thinks he or she has failed) to hear noise may try again, each attempt taking one round. However, no more than three attempts may be made the same character before the strain becomes too great and no further listening attempts will succeed until the character has rested for at least one turn.

If the check is successful, the GM should decide whether there is in fact any noise to be heard. Some monsters, such as bugbears, are stealthy and cannot be detected by listening. However, generally if there is some monster in the area and a “hear noise” check is passed, the party should gain some clue about what it is. Clever players whose characters speak various monster languages may gain valuable information from overhearing snatches of conversation—but the GM should be careful only to describe what characters can actually hear. So the GM would not normally say “you hear a giant spider,” but rather “you hear a scuttling, rattling sound” as the creature climbs to a suitable spot from which to ambush the party.

Don’t forget, monsters can hear the party in the same way as the party can hear them!
system.dmonlytext:
Listening for noise as often as possible, at every door and intersection, is an understandably common tactic, because it’s one of the easiest ways for players to improve the odds in their favour — so as to be able to make better-informed decisions about their actions. This is fine in moderation. However, if the pace of play slows considerably, diminishing the excitement and reducing the adventure to dice-rolling, the GM should discourage the players from endless listening attempts. Emphasise the inconvenience of donning and doffing helmets and headgear while the rest of the party stands around doing nothing; and if play is still slow, employ tricks that circumvent listening, e.g. silent monsters or phantom noises (perhaps due to strange acoustics in the dungeon or magic). In extreme cases the GM can place traps and monsters that specifically target listening characters, but before it gets to that, the GM should speak frankly to the players and explain that while some degree of caution is good play, carrying things to extremes only makes the game less fun.

Balance this against the lethality of the dungeon. In extremely dangerous areas, the players should not be punished for taking due care.

system.description: Infravision enables them to see up to 60 feet in the dark.

• 1 in 6 chance to notice secret doors when passing within 10 ft
  • 2 in 6 chance to discover secret doors when searching,
  • 3 in 6 chance to discover concealed doors when searching.
This is used to determine success on minor feats of strength such as forcing a dungeon door that doesn't open easily (this is the average dungeon door).
This is used to attempt an extraordinary success on minor feats of strength such as forcing a dungeon door enspelled by minor magics such as Hold Portal or Wizard Lock.

General

Clerics are moral and spiritual leaders, warriors of faith who preach the will of the gods, interpret omens and portents, and strike down the evil or unfaithful. Most clerics have a patron deity, but some are champions of a particular moral alignment, venerating all deities of that alignment in addition to a patron deity, and yet others are the servants of a particular pantheon of deities.

In a world of swords and sorcery, force of arms often speaks louder than moral suasion, and clerics are trained to do battle against the enemies of their gods. Some clerics are fanatics, zealously seeking new converts or hunting heretics. Others seem almost burdened by an inconvenient or even oppressive relationship with the divine forces. Evil clerics - sinister villains who prey upon fear and jealousy - sow discord in the world and gather converts for their demonic masters.

Clerics play an important support role for an adventuring party. Most clerical spells are oriented toward healing, strengthening, and defending others. However, when the need arises the cleric is fully capable of taking a place in the line of battle and smiting down infidels and foes.

Clerics employ their holy symbols rather than spell books as a focus for their meditation. Cleric spells are automatically acquired as the cleric gains levels and no check is necessary to ensure they are understood; thus clerics may normally memorise any spell appropriate to their level.

However, in some circumstances the powers the cleric serves may intervene and grant different spells to those requested; it is suggested that this is only done in extreme cases (such as when the cleric has been guilty of an alignment transgression of some kind, for example; more serious transgressions may result in fewer spells being granted, or even none at all).

Some GMs may permit clerics of specific deities to have slightly different abilities from those described here.

When a cleric attains ninth level, he or she has accumulated sufficient divine favour and mortal renown to found a temple/stronghold. Such places are normally carved from the wilderness, in the same manner as a fighter establishes a freehold. For a cleric to assume the leadership of an existing temple, the details are left to the discretion of the GM; a level somewhat higher than ninth might be required. Whether the cleric estab-lishes a stronghold or a temple, followers and acolytes will flock to the cleric's banner.

 

Minimum Scores: Str 6, Dex 3, Con 6, Int 6, Wis 9, Cha 6

 

Hit Die Type: d8 (max 9)

 

Alignment: Any

 

Experience bonus: Wisdom 16+

 

Armour/Shield Permitted: Any

 

Weapons Permitted: Blunt only - club, flail, hammer, mace, oil, staff; clerics may hurl hammers, clubs, or oil, but may not employ other missile weapons

 

Weapon Proficiencies: 2, +1 every 3 levels

 

Penalty to hit for non-proficiency: -3

 

Weapon Specialisation: N/A

 

Cleric Class Abilities

Spell Casting: Clerics may memorise and cast clerical spells in accordance with the tables provided hereafter.

 

Turning Undead: Clerics can "turn" the undead, making them flee from the cleric's holiness (or, in the case of an evil cleric, bringing them to heel as servants and minions). Because paladins are also capable of turning undead (though not with the same power as a cleric), rules for turning the undead are found later in this book rather than repeating them in the descriptions of both the paladin and cleric classes.

 

Bonus spells: These are awarded to clerics with high wisdom. They are not cumulative and are awarded by level; hence "2/2/1/1" means the cleric is granted 2 - 1st level, 2 - 2nd level, 1 - 3rd level, and 1 - 4th level bonus spells.

Wisdom Score Bonus Spells Chance of Spell Failure (d%)
9 0 15
10 0 10
11 0 5
12 0 1
13 1 0
14 2 0
15 2/1 0
16 2/2 0
17 2/2/1 0
18 2/2/1/1 0
19 3/2/1/1 0

 

Perceive Magical Surveillance (7th): [Foundry Note: the inclusion of this skill is a Foundry-specific addition.  Also please note that the specific target number for this skill is determined both by level and INT score, so 7th is simply the earliest level a cleric could possibly emply it.  See the skill description to determine the specific target number for any actor. If current level/INT doesn't qualify an actor to use the skill, set the target number to "0" until the actor does qualify. The target number likely requires adjustment in any case as levels are gained. - Ed.]
Capacity: 3 cu. ft. or 30 lbs

[Foundry Note: a common house rule was to give large shields (and only large shields) an additional +2 bonus vs normal missiles.  A passive effect is included which mimics this. It may be toggled on if your GM uses this house rule, although the GM may also require it toggled off on the occasion an attack is made against "shieldless" AC. - Ed.]

 

Allowed Classes

ACFPR

D (wooden only)

 

Details

Shields do NOT affect armour class where the target is being attacked from the rear.

Likewise, a figure attacked by several opponents may only employ the shield against a limited number of attacks per round:

  • one attack/round (small shield)
  • two attacks/round (medium shield)
  • three attacks/round (large shield)

Thus AC against multiple opponents will tend to deteriorate.

Allowed Classes

ACDFPR

 

Details

Strength damage bonus with missile weapons is restricted to hurled weapons (axes, hammers, clubs, darts, daggers, javelins and spears). 

Magic hand axes and hammers can be hurled up to 30 ft with the benefit of the magic attack bonus but losing the magic damage bonus.

 

Range Penalties

Range as Missile To-Hit Penalty
Short (1-10 ft) None
Medium (11-20 ft) -2
Long (21-30 ft) -5

Allowed Classes

CFPR

Allowed Classes

ACFPR
Capacity: 6 cu. ft. or 60 lbs

Range: 10/20/30; see Actions tab for ranged attack

Range as Missile To-Hit Penalty
Short (1-10 ft) None
Medium (11-20 ft) -2
Long (21-30 ft) -5

[Foundry Note: This is a Container-item that can be used on a character sheet to hold items carried on the horse (switch their status to "not carried" so their weight doesn't accumulate on the PC or NPC actor).  If the animal is needed for combat purposes, the actor linked below can be pulled on to the map/combat tracker with stats adjusted as appropriate. - Ed.]

Clerics can "turn" the undead, making them flee from the cleric's holiness (or, in the case of an evil cleric, bringing them to heel as servants and minions).

Paladins are also capable of turning undead starting at 3rd level (though not with the same power as a cleric).

Capacity: 1 cu. ft. or 10 lbs
Capacity: 4 cu. ft. or 40 lbs
Capacity: 4 cu. ft. or 40 lbs

Healing A character proficient in healing
knows how to use natural medicines and
basic principles of first aid and doctoring. If
the character tends another within one
round of wounding (and makes a successful
proficiency check), his ministrations restore
Id3 hit points (but no more hit points can be
restored than were lost in the previous
round). Only one healing attempt can be
made on a character per day.
If a wounded character remains under the
care of someone with healing proficiency,
that character can recover lost hit points at
the rate of 1 per day even when traveling or
engaging in nonstrenuous activity. If the
wounded character gets complete rest, he
can recover 2 hit points per day while under
such care. M y characters with both heal-
ing and herbalism proficiencies can help
others recover at the rate of 3 hit points per
day of rest. This care does not require a pro-
ficiency check, only the regular attention of
the proficient character. Up to six patients
can be cared for at any time.
A character with healing proficiency can
also attempt to aid a poisoned individual,
provided the poison entered through a
wound. If the poisoned character can be
tended to immediately (the round after the
character is poisoned) and the care con-
tinues for the next five rounds, the victim
gains a +2 bonus to his saving throw (delay
his saving throw until the last round of tend-
ing). No proficiency check is required, but
the poisoned character must be tended to
immediately (normally by sacrificing any
other action by the proficient character) and
cannot do anything himself. If the care and
rest are interrupted, the poisoned character
must immediately roll a normal saving
throw for the poison. This result is unalter-
able by normal means (Le., more healing
doesn't help). Only characters with both
healing and herbalism proficiencies can
attempt the same treatment for poisons the
victim has swallowed or touched (the char-
acter uses his healing to diagnose the poison
and his herbalist knowledge to prepare a
purgative).
A character with healing proficiency can
also attempt to diagnose and treat diseases.
When dealing with normal diseases, a suc-
cessful proficiency check automatically
reduces the disease to its mildest form and
shortest duration. Those who also have her-
balism knowledge gain an additional +2
bonus to this check. A proficient character
can also attempt to deal with magical dis-
eases, whether caused by spells or creatures.
In this case, a successful proficiency check
diagnoses the cause of the disease. How-
ever, since the disease is magical in nature, it
can be treated only by magical means.

ReadinglWriting: The character can read
and write a modern language he can speak,
provided there is someone available to teach
the character (another PC, a hireling, or an
NPC).This proficiency does not enable the
character to learn ancient languages (see
Languages, Ancient).

Religion: Characters with religion profi-
ciency know the common beliefs and cults
of their homeland and the major faiths of
neighboring regions. Ordinary information
(type of religious symbol used, basic atti-
tude of the faith, etc.) of any religion is
automatically known by the character. Sp-
cial information, such as how the clergy is
organized or the significance of particular
holy days, requires a proficiency check.
Additional proficiencies spent on religion
enable the character either to expand his
general knowledge into more distant
regions (using the guidelines above) or to
gain precise information about a single
faith. If the latter is chosen, the character is
no longer required to make a proficiency
check when answering questions about that
religion. Such expert knowledge is highly
useful to priest characters when dealing
with their own and rival faiths.

Riding, Land-Based: Those skilled in land
riding are proficient in the art of riding and
handling horses or other types of ground
mounts. When the proficiency slot is filled,
the character must declare which type of
mount he is proficient in. Possibilities
include griffons, unicorns, dire wolves, and
virtually any creatures used as mounts by
humans, demihumans, or humanoids.
A character with riding proficiency can
perform all of the following feats. Some of
them are automatic, while others require a
proficiency check for success.
The character can vault onto a saddle
whenever the horse or other mount is stand-
ing still, even when the character is wearing
armor. This does not require a proficiency
check. The character must make a check,
however, if he wishes to get the mount mov-
ing during the same round in which he lands
in its saddle. He must also make a proficien-
cy check if he attempts to vault onto the sad-
dle of a moving mount. Failure indicates
that the character falls to the ground-
presumably quite embarrassed.
The character can urge the mount to
jump tall obstacles or leap across gaps. No
check is required if the obstacle is less than
three feet tall or the gap is less than 12 feet
wide. If the character wants to roll a profi-
ciency check, the mount can be urged to
leap obstacles up to seven feet high, or jump
across gaps up to 30 feet wide. Success
means that the mount has made the jump.
Failure indicates that it balks, and the char-
acter must make another proficiency check
to see whether he retains his seat or falls to
the ground.
* The character can spur his steed on to
great speeds, adding 6 feet per round to the
animal's movement rate for up to four
turns. This requires a proficiency check
each turn to see if the mount can be pushed
this hard. If the initial check fails, no further
attempts may be made, but the mount can
move normally. If the second or subsequent
check fails, the mount immediately slows to
a walk, and the character must dismount
and lead the animal for a turn. In any event,
after four turns of racing, the steed must be
walked by its dismounted rider for one turn.
* The character can guide his mount with
hisknees, enabling him to use weapons that
two hands (such as bows and two-
EzG swords) while mounted. This feat
does not require a proficiency check unless
the character takes damage while so riding.
In this case, a check is required and failure
means that the character falls to the ground
and sustains an additional ld6 points of
damage.
* The character can drop down and hang
alongside the steed, using it as a shield
against attack. The character cannot make
an attack or wear armor while performing
this feat. The character’s Armor Class is
lowered by 6 while this maneuver is per-
forme+ Any attacks that would have struck
the character’s normal Armor Class are con-
sidered to have struck the mount instead.
No proficiency check is required.
* The character can leap from the back of
his steed to the ground and make a melee
attack against any character or creature
within 10 feet. The player must roll a suc-
cessful proficiency check with a -4 penalty
to succeed. On a failed roll, the character
fails to land on his feet, falls clumsily to the
grpund, and suffers Id3 points of damage.

The robe is very long, fully 7 feet, but

by use of the black cord belt each has, the hem can be

adjusted so as to just sweep the ground. The sleeves are

so long as to reach at least 1’ below the hands of even a

long-armed man. With each robe is a long, pointed hood

whose front and back points reach well down on the

wearer’s torso, and whose sides cover the shoulders. The

pointed front and back pieces are decorated with inverted,

two-tiered black pyramids. Each hood has narrow,

slanting eye holes. The pointed top extends a foot or

more above the crown of the wearer’s head.

Foundry Note: Once the torch is in a character's inventory, go into the cast action and set to Resource Item in the dropdown to "torch".  Use the cast action to deplete torches in inventory.   Target the torch holder and and apply the light effect to them to create light on the map for the duration (6 turns). - Ed.]

 

General

Torches shed 40 ft of illumination and burn out in 6 turns (1 hour).

actionGroups.name: Torch
actionGroups.description:
Foundry Note: Once the torch is in a character's inventory, go into the cast action and set to Resource Item in the dropdown to "torch".  Use the cast action to deplete torches in inventory.   Target the torch holder and and apply the light effect to them to create light on the map for the duration (6 turns). - Ed.]

 

General

Torches shed 40 ft of illumination and burn out in 6 turns (1 hour).

nwp.name: Healing
nwp.description: A character proficient in healing knows how to use natural medicines and basic principles of first aid and doctoring. If the character tends another within one round of wounding (and makes a successful proficiency check), his ministrations restore 1d3 hit points (but no more hit points can be restored than were lost in the previous round).

nwp.name: Herbalism
nwp.description: Those with herbalist knowledge can identify plants and fungi and prepare nonmagical potions, poultices, powders, balms, salves, ointments, infusions, and plasters for medical and pseudo-medical purposes. They can also prepare natural plant poisons and purgatives.

nwp.name: Reading/Writing
nwp.description: The character can read and write a modern language he can speak, provided there is someone available to teach the character (another player character, an NPC hireling, or an NPC hired for the purpose).

nwp.name: Religion
nwp.description: Characters with religion proficiency know the common beliefs and cults of their homeland and the major faiths of neighboring regions. Ordinary information (type of religious symbol used, basic attitude of the faith, etc.) of any religion is automatically known by the character.

nwp.name: Riding, Land-Based
nwp.description: Those skilled in land riding are proficient in the art of riding and handling horses or other types of ground mounts. When the proficiency slot is filled, the character must declare which type of mount he is proficient in.

nwp.name: Ancient History
nwp.description: The character has learned the legends, lore, and history of some ancient time and place. The knowledge must be specific, just as a historian would specialize today in the English Middle Ages, the Italian Renaissance, or the Roman Republic before Caesar.
